problems.problem: Define fiscal policy and give its main objectives.

step_by_step.explanation: Fiscal policy is the use of government spending and taxation to influence economic activity.
Main objectives: stimulate growth, reduce unemployment, control inflation, and stabilize the economy.

problems.final_answer: Fiscal policy: government spending/taxes to influence economy; objectives: growth, employment, inflation control, stabilization.

problems.problem: Differentiate expansionary and contractionary monetary policy.

step_by_step.explanation: Lower interest rates or increase money supply to stimulate aggregate demand.
Raise interest rates or reduce money supply to reduce inflation.

problems.final_answer: Expansionary: ↓ interest rates/↑ money supply; Contractionary: ↑ interest rates/↓ money supply.

problems.problem: List the main tools of monetary policy.

step_by_step.explanation: Open market operations, discount rate, reserve requirement, interest on reserves, quantitative easing.

problems.final_answer: Monetary policy tools: OMO, discount rate, reserve requirement, interest on reserves, QE.

problems.problem: Explain the money creation process by commercial banks.

step_by_step.explanation: Banks lend out deposits while keeping a fraction as reserves; loans are redeposited and re-lent, increasing the money supply via the multiplier effect.

problems.final_answer: Money creation: lending deposits → redeposits → repeated lending → money multiplier effect.

problems.problem: Draw and explain the short-run Phillips Curve trade-off.

step_by_step.explanation: SRPC shows inverse relationship between unemployment and inflation: policies that increase AD lower unemployment but raise inflation.

problems.final_answer: SRPC: ↑ AD → ↓ unemployment, ↑ inflation; inverse short-run trade-off.

problems.problem: Explain automatic stabilizers in fiscal policy.

step_by_step.explanation: Built-in government mechanisms (like taxes and transfer payments) that automatically counteract fluctuations in aggregate demand without new legislation.

problems.final_answer: Automatic stabilizers: built-in fiscal mechanisms that reduce economic fluctuations automatically.

problems.problem: Differentiate short-run and long-run Phillips Curve.

step_by_step.explanation: Shows trade-off between inflation and unemployment in short run.
Vertical at natural rate of unemployment; no long-term trade-off exists.

problems.final_answer: SRPC: short-run trade-off; LRPC: vertical, unemployment = natural rate.

problems.problem: Explain crowding out in fiscal policy.

step_by_step.explanation: When government spending raises interest rates, reducing private investment and partially offsetting the expansionary effect.

problems.final_answer: Crowding out: ↑ government spending → ↑ interest rates → ↓ private investment.

problems.problem: Explain demand-pull and cost-push inflation using AD/AS and Phillips Curve.

step_by_step.explanation: Increase in AD shifts AD curve right → lowers unemployment temporarily, increases inflation along SRPC.
Decrease in AS shifts SRAS left → increases unemployment and inflation, SRPC shifts up.

problems.final_answer: Demand-pull: ↑ AD → ↑ inflation, ↓ unemployment; Cost-push: ↓ AS → ↑ inflation & ↑ unemployment.
